instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text
input: What types of constant volume fans does the AirflowNetwork model allow?
output: The AirflowNetwork model currently allows two types of constant volume fans: Fan:ConstantVolume and Fan:OnOff.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text
input: What operation mode does the Fan:ConstantVolume object have?
output: The Fan:ConstantVolume object has only one type of supply air fan operation mode: continuous fan cycling compressor (ContinuousFanWithCyclingCompressor).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text
input: What operation modes does the Fan:OnOff object have?
output: The Fan:OnOff has two types of supply air fan operation modes: cycling fan cycling compressor (CyclingFanAndCompressor) or continuous fan cycling compressor (ContinuousFanWithCyclingCompressor).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text
input: What is the CyclingFanAndCompressor operation mode frequently referred to as?
output: The CyclingFanAndCompressor operation mode is frequently referred to as 'AUTO fan'.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text
input: What is the outdoor air mass flow rate measured in?
output: The outdoor air mass flow rate is measured in kilograms per second [kg/s].

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> equation
input: What does the equation for the total sensible load in the i-th zone due to ADS losses look like?
output: The equation is: Q_ADSi = \\sum_j Q_cond(ij) + \\sum_j Q_leak(ij)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> equation
input: What does the equation for the total latent load in the i-th zone due to ADS losses look like?
output: The equation is: Q_ADSmi = \\sum_j Q_condm(ij) + \\sum_j Q_leakm(ij)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> table
input: What is the total sensible load in the i-th zone due to ADS losses?
output: The total sensible load in the i-th zone due to ADS losses is represented by Q_ADSi and measured in watts [W].

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> table
input: What is the duct wall conduction loss at the j-th duct located in the i-th zone?
output: The duct wall conduction loss at the j-th duct located in the i-th zone is represented by Q_cond(ij) and measured in watts [W].

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> table
input: What is the sensible supply leak loss at the j-th linkage located in the i-th zone?
output: The sensible supply leak loss at the j-th linkage located in the i-th zone is represented by Q_leak(ij) and measured in watts [W].

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> table
input: What is the total latent load in the i-th zone due to ADS losses?
output: The total latent load in the i-th zone due to ADS losses is represented by Q_ADSmi and measured in kilograms per second [kg/s].

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> table
input: What is the duct wall vapor diffusion loss at the j-th duct located in the i-th zone?
output: The duct wall vapor diffusion loss at the j-th duct located in the i-th zone is represented by Q_condm(ij) and measured in kilograms per second [kg/s].

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> table
input: What is the latent supply leak loss at the j-th linkage located in the i-th zone?
output: The latent supply leak loss at the j-th linkage located in the i-th zone is represented by Q_leakm(ij) and measured in kilograms per second [kg/s].

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text
input: What types of constant volume fans does the AirflowNetwork model currently allow?
output: The AirflowNetwork model currently allows two types of constant volume fans: Fan:ConstantVolume and Fan:OnOff.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text
input: What is the only type of supply air fan operation mode for the Fan:ConstantVolume object?
output: The only type of supply air fan operation mode for the Fan:ConstantVolume object is continuous fan cycling compressor (ContinuousFanWithCyclingCompressor).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text
input: What are the two types of supply air fan operation modes for the Fan:OnOff?
output: The two types of supply air fan operation modes for the Fan:OnOff are cycling fan cycling compressor (CyclingFanAndCompressor) and continuous fan cycling compressor (ContinuousFanWithCyclingCompressor).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text
input: What is the CyclingFanAndCompressor operation mode frequently referred to as?
output: The CyclingFanAndCompressor operation mode is frequently referred to as 'AUTO fan'.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text
input: What is the ContinuousFanWithCyclingCompressor operation mode often referred to as?
output: The ContinuousFanWithCyclingCompressor operation mode is often referred to as 'fan ON'.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text
input: How is the supply air fan operation mode specified?
output: The supply air fan operation mode is specified in an HVAC system object based on a given fan operation mode schedule.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text
input: What is the determination of the zone sensible and latent loads dependent on?
output: The determination of the zone sensible and latent loads is dependent on the supply air fan operation mode.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text
input: Where are the zone loads calculated by the AirflowNetwork model added?
output: The zone loads calculated by the AirflowNetwork model are added to zone sensible and latent balances in the ZonePredictorCorrector module.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text
input: In the case of continuous fan/cycling compressor how are the zone loads during forced air distribution system operation calculated?
output: In the case of continuous fan/cycling compressor the zone loads during forced air distribution system operation are calculated with the system design air mass flow rate without modification.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text
input: In the case of cycling fan/cycling compressor how are the airflows determined?
output: In the case of cycling fan/cycling compressor the airflows are determined based on the air distribution system part-load ratio.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text
input: When are the airflows for the AirflowNetwork:Distribution:Linkage objects reported?
output: The airflows for the AirflowNetwork:Distribution:Linkage objects are reported during the air distribution system on cycle.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text
input: How are the airflows for the AirflowNetwork:Multizone:Surface objects weighted?
output: The airflows for the AirflowNetwork:Multizone:Surface objects are weighted by the air distribution system.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text
input: How do the air fan and compressor operate to meet the zone heating or cooling load?
output: The air fan and compressor operate in unison to meet the zone heating or cooling load and cycle off together when the heating or cooling load has been met.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text
input: What is the ContinuousFanWithCyclingCompressor operation mode often referred to as?
output: The ContinuousFanWithCyclingCompressor operation mode is often referred to as 'fan ON'.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text
input: How does the supply air fan operate in the ContinuousFanWithCyclingCompressor mode?
output: In the ContinuousFanWithCyclingCompressor mode the supply air fan operates continuously regardless of compressor operation.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text
input: How is the supply air fan operation mode specified?
output: The supply air fan operation mode is specified in an HVAC system object based on a given fan operation mode schedule (e.g. AirLoopHVAC:UnitaryHeatCool object).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text
input: On what does the determination of the zone sensible and latent loads depend?
output: The determination of the zone sensible and latent loads depends on the supply air fan operation mode.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text
input: Where are the zone loads calculated by the AirflowNetwork model added?
output: The zone loads calculated by the AirflowNetwork model are added to zone sensible and latent balances in the ZonePredictorCorrector module.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text
input: How are zone air temperatures and humidity ratios calculated?
output: Zone air temperatures and humidity ratios are calculated by adding the zone loads to zone sensible and latent balances in the ZonePredictorCorrector module.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text
input: How are the zone loads during forced air distribution system operation calculated for the continuous fan/cycling compressor case?
output: For the continuous fan/cycling compressor case the zone loads during forced air distribution system operation are calculated with the system design air mass flow rate without modification.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text
input: How are airflows determined for the cycling fan/cycling compressor case?
output: For the cycling fan/cycling compressor case airflows are determined based on the air distribution system part-load ratio.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text
input: When are airflows for the AirflowNetwork:Distribution:Linkage objects reported?
output: Airflows for the AirflowNetwork:Distribution:Linkage objects are reported during the air distribution system on cycle.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text
input: How are airflows for the AirflowNetwork:Multizone:Surface objects weighted?
output: Airflows for the AirflowNetwork:Multizone:Surface objects are weighted by the air distribution system part-load ratio.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text
input: What are zone loads a sum of?
output: Zone loads are the sum of energy losses during both the air distribution system on and off cycle at each system time step.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text
input: How are energy losses calculated when the air distribution system is on?
output: Energy losses when the air distribution system is on are calculated using the system 'on' air flow rate multiplied by the air distribution system run time fraction.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text
input: How are energy losses obtained when the air distribution system is off?
output: Energy losses when the air distribution system is off are obtained from the multizone airflow calculations and multiplied by (1.0 - system run time fraction).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> table: Airflow
input: What is the formula for calculating airflow?
output: Airflow = Airflow during ADS on cycle * ADS Part-load ratio + Airflow during ADS off cycle * (1.0 - ADS Part-load ratio)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> table row: Airflow
input: What does ADS stand for?
output: ADS stands for Air Distribution System.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> table: Zone load
input: What is the system run time fraction?
output: System run time fraction = Maximum run time fraction of coils and fans in the air distribution system.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> table row: Zone load
input: How are zone energy losses calculated?
output: Zone energy losses = Zone energy loss during ADS on cycle * System run time fraction + Zone energy loss during ADS off cycle * (1.0 - System run time fraction).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text
input: When is the calculation of loads due to multizone airflow performed?
output: The calculation of loads due to multizone airflow is performed when the HVAC system is first simulated during a simulation time step (FirstHVACIteration = True).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text
input: When is the calculation of loads due to air distribution system operation performed?
output: The calculation of loads due to air distribution system operation is performed on subsequent iterations within the same simulation time step when the mass flow rate at the supply air fan inlet is greater than 0.0 (and FirstHVACIteration = False).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text
input: What are zone loads in the context of the air distribution system?
output: Zone loads are the sum of energy losses during both the air distribution system on and off cycle at each system time step.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text
input: How are energy losses calculated when the air distribution system is on?
output: Energy losses when the air distribution system is on are calculated using the system on air flow rate multiplied by the air distribution system run time fraction.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text
input: How are energy losses calculated when the air distribution system is off?
output: Energy losses when the air distribution system is off are obtained from the multizone airflow calculations and are multiplied by (1.0 - system run time fraction).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text
input: What assumption is made about airflows when the fan is off?
output: It is assumed that there are no airflows through the air distribution system when the fan is off.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> table: Airflow calculation
input: What is the formula for calculating airflow?
output: Airflow = Airflow during ADS on cycle * ADS Part-load ratio + Airflow during ADS off cycle * (1.0 - ADS Part-load ratio)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> table row: Airflow calculation
input: What does ADS stand for?
output: ADS stands for Air Distribution System.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> table: Zone load calculation
input: What is the formula for calculating system run time fraction?
output: System run time fraction = Maximum run time fraction of coils and fans in the air distribution system

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> table row: Zone load calculation
input: How are zone energy losses calculated?
output: Zone energy losses = Zone energy loss during ADS on cycle * System run time fraction + Zone energy loss during ADS off cycle * (1.0 - System run time fraction)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text
input: When is the calculation of loads due to multizone airflow performed?
output: The calculation of loads due to multizone airflow is performed when the HVAC system is first simulated during a simulation time step (FirstHVACIteration = True).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text
input: When is the calculation of loads due to air distribution system operation performed?
output: The calculation of loads due to air distribution system operation is performed on subsequent iterations within the same simulation time step when the mass flow rate at the supply air fan inlet is greater than 0.0 (and FirstHVACIteration = False).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text

output: The AirflowNetwork model currently allows a variable air volume fan type as Fan:VariableVolume.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text
input: What causes the pressure difference between the two opening locations?
output: There is a pressure difference Δp(t) between the two opening locations with time-averaged mean value \\overlineΔp and standard deviation \\sigma_Δp.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text
input: What are the three principal mechanisms determining the flow rate?
output: There are three principal mechanisms determining the flow rate: mean pressure difference unsteady pressure difference and shear layer mechanism.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text
input: How does the mean pressure difference mechanism work?
output: Mean pressure difference: a non-zero mean value for the difference in pressure at the two opening locations \\overlineΔp drives a flow that scales as \\overlineΔp^1/2.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text
input: How does the unsteady pressure difference mechanism work?
output: Unsteady pressure difference: turbulence drives a fluctuating pressure difference between the two openings resulting in a net addition of air from the outside. This is characterized by the standard deviation of the pressure difference signal \\sigma_Δp and the associated flow rate adds to that arising from \\overlineΔp. It includes periodic Strouhal forcing ('pumping ) at relevant wind angles. Note that this contribution is non-zero even when the mean pressure difference is zero.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text
input: How does the shear layer mechanism work?
output: Shear layer mechanism: when there is small or zero mean pressure difference between the two opening locations the local flow parallel to the façade causes a mixing layer to grow over the length of the opening resulting in the incorporation of ambient air. This scales with U_L.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text
input: How does the model view the flow rate?
output: Our model therefore views the flow rate as comprising contributions from each of these as appropriate i.e. Q =\\left[a_p |Δc_p |+a_σ \\sigma_Δ

output: In the 2-aperture case air flows in through one opening of area $A_\\textupin$ and exits through another of equal area.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> equation

output: The dimensionless flow rate $Q$ is defined by $Q =Q/(A_\\textupin U_\\textupref)$.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text
input: What is $U_\\textupref$?
output: $U_\\textupref$ is a reference velocity taken as the undisturbed wind speed $U(z_\\textupref)$ at a reference height $z_\\textupref = 10 \\textupm$.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text
input: What is the pressure difference between the two opening locations?
output: There is a pressure difference $\\Delta p(t)$ between the two opening locations with time-averaged mean value $\\overline\\Delta p$ and standard deviation $\\sigma_\\Delta p$.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text
input: What are the three principal mechanisms determining the flow rate?
output: The three principal mechanisms determining the flow rate are: (a) Mean pressure difference (b) Unsteady pressure difference and (c) Shear layer mechanism.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text
input: What drives a flow that scales as $\\overline\\Delta p^1/2$?
output: A non-zero mean value for the difference in pressure at the two opening locations $\\overline\\Delta p$ drives a flow that scales as $\\overline\\Delta p^1/2$.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text
input: What characterizes the unsteady pressure difference?
output: The unsteady pressure difference is characterized by the standard deviation of the pressure difference signal $\\sigma_\\Delta p$ and includes periodic Strouhal forcing at relevant wind angles.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text

output: The shear layer mechanism causes a mixing layer to grow over the length of the opening resulting in the incorporation of ambient air.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> equation

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text
input: How are the two openings positioned in the fa\\ccade?
output: The two openings are a distance $s$ apart in a fa\\ccade of width WB whose normal has azimuthal angle $\\varphi_n$.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text
input: What is the wind direction relative to the fa\\ccade?
output: The wind azimuthal direction is $\\varphi_w$ so that its direction relative to the fa\\ccade is $\\theta=\\varphi_w-\\varphi_n$.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text
input: What are the limits for $\\varphi_n$ $\\varphi_w$ and $\\theta$?
output: In these definitions $\\ang0 \\leq \\varphi_n \\varphi_w \\leq \\ang360$ while $|\\theta| \\leq \\ang180$.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text
input: What should be done if $\\theta$ initially falls outside the indicated range?
output: If $\\theta$ initially falls outside the range indicated it should be replaced by $\\operatornamesign(\\theta) \\left[|\\theta| - \\ang360\\right]$.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> equation
input: How is the flow rate modeled in terms of mean and fluctuating components?
output: The flow rate is modeled as $Q =\\left(a_p |\\Delta c_p |+a_\\sigma \\sigma_\\Delta c_p \\right)^1/2$.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> equation
input: What is the equation for the pressure coefficient difference?
output: \\Delta c_p=\\frac\\overline\\Delta p\\frac12 \\rho U_\\textupref^2

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> equation
input: What is the equation for the standard deviation of the pressure coefficient difference?
output: \\sigma_\\Delta c_p=\\frac\\sigma_\\Delta p\\frac12 \\rho U_\\textupref^2

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> equation
input: What is the equation for the non-dimensional wind speed?
output: U_L =\\fracU_LU_\\textupref

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text
input: What is the dominant pressure-difference mechanism for the 2-opening case?
output: The pressure-difference mechanisms \\refss-mean-mech and \\refss-unsteady-mech are dominant for the 2-opening case and \\refss-shear-mech is negligible.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text
input: What is the dominant pressure-difference mechanism for the single opening case?
output: In the case of a single opening shear is dominant.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text
input: What constants are set to zero for the 2-opening and single opening cases?
output: We take $a_s=0$ for 2-opening cases and $a_p = a_\\sigma = 0$ for one opening.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text
input: What does the document focus on henceforth?
output: Henceforth we focus on the 2-opening case although a procedure is given at the end of the section for how to approximate a greater number by just two.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> figure in /UAStudy/EnergyPlus/doc/engineering-reference/media/
input: What does Figure \\reffig:ss-plan-view-two-openings depict?
output: Plan view of building with 2-opening fa\\ccade.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text
input: How are the two openings structured in the facade?
output: The two openings are a distance $s$ apart in a fa\\ccade of width WB whose normal has azimuthal angle $\\varphi_n$.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text
input: What is the wind azimuthal direction?
output: The wind azimuthal direction is $\\varphi_w$ so that its direction relative to the fa\\ccade is $\\theta=\\varphi_w-\\varphi_n$.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> equation
input: What is the equation for the wind direction relative to the facade?
output: \\theta=\\varphi_w-\\varphi_n

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text
input: What are the ranges for $\\varphi_n$ $\\varphi_w$ and $\\theta$?
output: In these definitions $\\ang0 \\leq \\varphi_n \\varphi_w \\leq \\ang360$ while $|\\theta| \\leq \\ang180$.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text
input: What should be done if $\\theta$ falls outside the indicated range?
output: If $\\theta$ initially falls outside the range indicated it should be replaced by $\\operatornamesign(\\theta) \\left[|\\theta| - \\ang360\\right]$.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text
input: How is the flow rate modeled?
output: The flow rate is modeled as comprising two terms arising respectively from the mean and fluctuating components of the pressure difference between the two aperture locations.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> equation
input: What is the equation for the flow rate in terms of pressure coefficients?
output: Q =\\left(a_p |\\Delta c_p |+a_\\sigma \\sigma_\\Delta c_p \\right)^1/2

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text
input: What are the two parts to deriving the detailed form of the model?
output: There are two parts to deriving the detailed form of the model: 1) Express the mean and fluctuating pressures in terms of other physical quantities that are more readily accessible. 2) Find the coefficients $a_p$ and $a_\\sigma$.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text
input: What does EnergyPlus lack information about?
output: EnergyPlus does not have the information on variations in pressure that is needed to compute $\\Delta c_p$ and $\\sigma_\\Delta c_p$.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text
input: How are expressions for $\\Delta c_p$ and $\\sigma_\\Delta c_p$ derived?
output: Analysis of wind tunnel pressure data (Linden et al. 2013) allows for the derivation of simple expressions for these quantities in terms of the wind direction and opening separation $s$.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text
input: How are the coefficients $a_p$ and $a_\\sigma$ found?
output: This is achieved here by analysis of ventilation rate data (Linden et al. 2013) and using linear regression on the data.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text
input: What did the analysis of pressure data show about the contributions to the right-hand side of Equation \\refeqn:ss-flow-two-terms?
output: The analysis of pressure data carried out showed that the contributions to the right-hand side of Equation \\refeqn:ss-flow-two-terms can be written to first order as $\\Delta c_p=f(s \\theta)$ and $\\sigma_\\Delta c_p=g(s \\theta)$.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> equation
input: What is the equation for the pressure coefficient difference as a function of separation and angle?
output: \\Delta c_p=f(s \\theta)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> equation
input: What is the equation for the standard deviation of the pressure coefficient difference as a function of separation and angle?
output: \\sigma_\\Delta c_p=g(s \\theta)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text
input: How do the pressure difference mean and standard deviation vary with opening separation?
output: To a first approximation the pressure difference mean and standard deviation vary linearly with opening separation each modulated by its own function of relative wind angle $\\theta$.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> equation
input: What is the equation for the dimensionless separation?
output: s = s/\\textupWB

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> equation
input: What is the equation for the function $f(s \\theta)$?
output: f(s \\theta)=s \\cdot\\Pi(\\theta)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> equation
input: What is the equation for the function $g(s \\theta)$?
output: g(s \\theta)=\\Sigma_0+s \\cdot\\Sigma(\\theta)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> equation
input: What is the first formula for $\\Pi(\\theta)$?
output: \\Pi(\\theta) = \\begincases 0.44\\operatornamesgn(\\theta)\\sin(2.67|\\theta|)& |\\theta| \\leq \\theta_0 \\\\ -0.69 \\operatornamesgn(\\theta)\\sin(288-1.6|\\theta|)& \\theta_0\\leq|\\theta|\\leq\\ang180. \\endcases

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> equation

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text
input: When is the flow Q defined to be positive?
output: The flow Q is defined to be positive when opening \\#1 is the inlet and opening \\#2 is the outlet.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text
input: Under what conditions can the flow Q be positive?
output: Q > 0 if \\ang0 < \\theta < \\theta_0 or \\ang-180 < \\theta < -\\theta_0.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> equation
input: What are the conditions for Q based on wind angles?
output: Q < 0\\ \\textotherwise\\\\ Q > 0\\ \\textif\\ \\ang0 < \\theta < \\theta_0\\ \\textor\\ \\ang-180 < \\theta < -\\theta_0

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text
input: Is the sense of Q well-defined for all angles?
output: The sense of Q is not necessarily well-defined for all such angles e.g. when the unsteady contribution in Equation \\refeqn:ss-flow-two-terms is significant: nevertheless we retain this definition for all angles.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> figure in /UAStudy/EnergyPlus/doc/engineering-reference/media/
input: What does Figure \\reffig:ss-figure-3-in-original depict?

Cases in the left-hand column (a)-(c) are for $s =0.75$ those in right-hand column (d)-(f) $s =0.32$. The three rows are for 2-story isolated 4-story isolated and 2-story with low-density surroundings respectively.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text
input: What is the purpose of inverting the flow rate to obtain the equivalent pressure difference?
output: The purpose of this procedure is to allow incorporation of the model into the network airflow part of EnergyPlus which requires pressure coefficients to calculate the flow rate: in this way the model will become essentially transparent to the user.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> equation
input: What is the equation for the non-dimensional flow rate Q?
output: \\fracQA_\\textin U_\\textref=\\left(0.01+\\left[0.173 |\\Pi(\\theta)|+0.042 \\Sigma(\\theta)\\right]s \\right)^1/2

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text
input: How is the flow Q defined in terms of inlet and outlet?
output: The flow Q is defined to be positive when opening #1 is the inlet and opening #2 is the outlet.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text
input: Under what condition can the flow Q be positive?
output: Since \\Delta p is defined as p_1-p_2 this can occur when \\Delta c_p > 0 which in turn corresponds to certain relative wind angles.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> equation
input: What are the conditions for Q to be less than or greater than zero?
output: Q < 0\\ \\textotherwise\\\\ Q > 0\\ \\textif\\ \\ang0 < \\theta < \\theta_0\\ \\textor\\ \\ang-180 < \\theta < -\\theta_0

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text
input: Is the sense of Q well-defined for all angles?
output: Note that the sense of Q is not necessarily well-defined for all such angles e.g. when the unsteady contribution in Equation \\refeqn:ss-flow-two-terms is significant: nevertheless we retain this definition for all angles.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> figure in /UAStudy/EnergyPlus/doc/engineering-reference/media/

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text
input: What is the purpose of inverting the flow rate to obtain the equivalent pressure difference?
output: The purpose of this procedure is to allow incorporation of the model into the network airflow part of EnergyPlus which requires pressure coefficients to calculate the flow rate: in this way the model will become essentially transparent to the user.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> figure in /UAStudy/EnergyPlus/doc/engineering-reference/media/
input: What is shown in Figure 4?
output: Pressure network for 2-opening single-sided room.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text
input: How are the openings and flow rate defined in the pressure network?
output: Here 0 is the ambient 1 is at the upstream outer surface 2 is at the downstream outer surface and R is the room. Let the openings have areas A_1 and A_2 not necessarily equal and a discharge coefficient C_d which is assumed equal and let Q be the flow rate through the system.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> equation
input: How is the pressure difference between two openings related to the flow rate?
output: \\frac\\Delta p_12\\frac12\\rho V^2 = \\frac1C_d^2\\left(\\fracQ/A_\\texteffV\\right)^2

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> equation
input: How is the effective area A_eff defined?
output: A_\\texteff=\\fracA_1 A_2\\left(A_1^2+A_2^2\\right)^1/2

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text
input: What is the reference velocity V used for?
output: V is a reference velocity.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text
input: What is the left-hand side of Equation \\refeqn:ss-delta-p-1-2 called?
output: The left-hand side of Equation \\refeqn:ss-delta-p-1-2 is a pressure coefficient \\Delta c_p12^E+ say.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text
input: What is the task related to the pressure coefficient \\Delta c_p12^E+?
output: Our task is to express this in terms of the flow rate in Equation \\refeqn:ss-combined-eqn but using the definition of a pressure coefficient appropriate to EnergyPlus.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> equation
input: How can Equation \\refeqn:ss-delta-p-1-2 be rewritten?
output: \\Delta c_p12^E+ = \\frac1C_d^2 \\left(\\fracA_\\textinA_\\texteff\\right)^2 \\left(\\fracU_\\textrefV\\right)^2 Q ^2

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text
input: What is the non-dimensional flow rate Q expressed in terms of?
output: Q = Q/(A_\\textinU_\\textref) is the non-dimensional flow rate of Equation \\refeqn:ss-combined-eqn which is expressed in terms of Q the window area A_\\textin and the wind speed at 10 m height U_\\textref.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text
input: What is the value of the factor \\left(A_\\textin/A_\\texteff\\right)^2?
output: The factor \\left(A_\\textin/A_\\texteff\\right)^2 = 2 since A_1 = A_2 = A_\\textin and therefore A_\\texteff = A_\\textin/\\sqrt2.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text
input: How can the factor (U_\\textref/V) be simplified?
output: The factor (U_\\textref/V) relating the velocity scale used in the correlation with that used in the EnergyPlus pressure coefficient may be simplified by noting the following.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> figure in /UAStudy/EnergyPlus/doc/engineering-reference/media/
input: What does the figure illustrate?
output: The figure illustrates the pressure network for a 2-opening single-sided room.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text
input: What are the labels used in the pressure network?
output: In the pressure network 0 is the ambient 1 is at the upstream outer surface 2 is at the downstream outer surface and R is the room.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text
input: What are the areas and discharge coefficient of the openings?
output: The openings have areas A_1 and A_2 not necessarily equal and a discharge coefficient C_d which is assumed equal.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text
input: What is the flow rate through the system denoted by?
output: The flow rate through the system is denoted by Q.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> equation
input: How is the pressure difference between the two openings related to the flow rate?
output: The pressure difference between the two openings Δp_12 is related to the flow rate by the equation: Δp_12/(0.5ρV^2) = (1/C_d^2)((Q/A_eff)/V)^2.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> equation
input: How is the effective area A_eff defined?
output: The effective area A_eff is defined by the equation: A_eff = (A_1 A_2)/((A_1^2 + A_2^2)^(1/2)).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text
input: What is V in the context of the equation?
output: V is a reference velocity.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text
input: What is the left-hand side of Equation refeqn:ss-delta-p-1-2 referred to as?
output: The left-hand side of Equation refeqn:ss-delta-p-1-2 is referred to as a pressure coefficient Δc_p12^E+.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text
input: What is the first step to express the pressure coefficient in terms of the flow rate?
output: The first step is to re-write Equation refeqn:ss-delta-p-1-2 as Δc_p12^E+ = (1/C_d^2)((A_in/A_eff)^2)(U_ref/V)^2 Q^2.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text
input: How is Q defined in the context of the equation?
output: Q is defined as Q = Q/(A_in U_ref) the non-dimensional flow rate of Equation refeqn:ss-combined-eqn expressed in terms of Q the window area A_in and the wind speed at 10 m height U_ref.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text
input: What is the factor (A_in/A_eff)^2 equal to and why?
output: The factor (A_in/A_eff)^2 is equal to 2 since A_1 = A_2 = A_in and therefore A_eff = A_in/√2.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text
input: What simplification can be made regarding the velocity scale used in the correlation?
output: The factor (U_ref/V) relating the velocity scale used in the correlation with that used in the EnergyPlus pressure coefficient may be simplified by noting that the reference velocity V = V_ref(z_win).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> equation
input: How is the surface pressure due to wind p_w derived in EnergyPlus?
output: In EnergyPlus the surface pressure due to wind p_w is derived from a pressure coefficient C_p using the local wind speed at window height V_ref(z_win) as: p_w = ρ_a [V_ref(z_win)]^2 C_p/2.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text
input: How is the vertical wind profile characterized in EnergyPlus?
output: EnergyPlus characterizes the vertical wind profile as a power law in z defined in terms of the local atmospheric boundary layer depth δ and a power law exponent α.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text
input: What formula does EnergyPlus use to derive the local wind speed from the meteorological site?
output: EnergyPlus uses an interpolation formula to derive the local wind speed from that measured at the meteorological site U_met according to: V_ref(z) = U_met (δ_met/z)^α_met (z/δ)^α.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text
input: What are the default values for the meteorological site conditions?
output: The default values for the meteorological site conditions are z_met = 10 m δ_met = 270 m and α_met = 0.14.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text
input: What is the reference velocity assumed in Equation refeqn:ss-combined-eqn?
output: The reference velocity assumed in Equation refeqn:ss-combined-eqn is the wind speed at 10 m which will be taken as the local velocity at the building V_ref(10).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> equation
input: What is the expression for the pressure coefficient representing the difference in pressure between the two openings?
output: The expression for the pressure coefficient representing the difference in pressure between the two openings is: Δc_p12^E+ = (1/C_d^2) [(V_ref(10)/V_ref(z_win))^2] (0.02 + [0.346 |Π(θ)| + 0.084 Σ(θ)]·s).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> equation
input: How is the velocity ratio V_ref(10)/V_ref(z_win) defined?
output: The velocity ratio V_ref(10)/V_ref(z_win) is defined as: (10/z_win)^α.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text
input: What pressure coefficients are assigned to openings 1 and 2?
output: A pressure coefficient +0.5Δc_p12^E+ is assigned to opening 1 and -0.5Δc_p12^E+ to opening 2.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text
input: How is the wind pressure denoted as $p_w$ derived?
output: The wind pressure $p_w$ is derived from a pressure coefficient $C_p$ using the local wind speed at window height $V_\\textref(z_\\textwin)$.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> equation
input: What is the equation for wind pressure $p_w$?
output: $p_w=\\rho_a \\left[V_\\textref(z_\\textwin)\\right]^2 C_p/2$

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text
input: What is the reference velocity in this context?
output: The reference velocity is $V = V_\\textref(z_\\textwin)$.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text
input: How does EnergyPlus characterize the vertical wind profile?
output: EnergyPlus characterizes the vertical wind profile as a power law in z defined in terms of the local atmospheric boundary layer depth $\\delta$ and a power law exponent $\\alpha$.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text
input: What formula does EnergyPlus use to derive the local wind speed?
output: EnergyPlus uses an interpolation formula to derive the local wind speed from that measured at the meteorological site $U_\\textmet$.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> equation
input: What is the equation for the local wind speed $V_\\textref(z)$?
output: $V_\\textref(z)= U_\\textmet \\left(\\frac\\delta_\\textmetz\\right)^\\alpha_\\textmet \\left(\\fracz\\delta\\right)^\\alpha$

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text
input: What are the default values for the meteorological site conditions?
output: The default values are $z_\\textmet = 10\\ \\textm$ $\\delta_\\textmet = 270\\ \\textm$ and $\\alpha_\\textmet = 0.14$.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text
input: Can the user change the site parameters from their default values?
output: Yes the user can change the site parameters from their default values.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text
input: What does the correlation in Equation \\refeqn:ss-combined-eqn assume about the reference velocity?
output: The correlation assumes the reference velocity is the wind speed at 10 m which will be taken as the local velocity at the building $V_\\textref(10)$.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> equation
input: What is the equation for the pressure coefficient $\\Delta c_p12^E+$?
output: $\\Delta c_p12^E+ = \\frac1C_d^2 \\left[ \\fracV_\\textref(10)V_\\textref(z_\\textwin) \\right]^2 \\left(0.02+\\left[0.346 |\\Pi(\\theta)|+0.084 \\Sigma(\\theta)\\right]\\cdots \\right)$

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> equation
input: What is the equation for the velocity ratio?
output: $\\fracV_\\textref(10)V_\\textref(z_\\textwin) = \\left(\\frac10z_\\textwin\\right)^\\alpha$

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text
input: How are pressure coefficients assigned to openings 1 and 2?
output: A pressure coefficient $+0.5\\Delta c_p12^E+$ is assigned to opening 1 and $-0.5\\Delta c_p12^E+$ to opening 2 to provide the necessary pressure difference for flow.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text
input: What does the pressure coefficient $\\Delta c_p12^E+$ refer to?
output: The pressure coefficient $\\Delta c_p12^E+$ refers to the difference in pressure between the two openings and is defined in terms of the wind speed at window height.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text
input: What is important when combining $\\Delta c_p12^E+$ with a background pressure coefficient for the facade?
output: It is important to ensure that both are defined using the same reference velocity.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> figure in /UAStudy/EnergyPlus/doc/engineering-reference/media/

output: Figure 5 shows the local velocity as a function of wind angle for wind tunnel data analyzed. On the 2-story graph 'WP85' refers to Warren and Parkins (1985) whose measurement location is most closely matched by the 'Center' curve.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> figure in /UAStudy/EnergyPlus/doc/engineering-reference/media/

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text

output: The SS model was developed using wind tunnel pressure and flow rate data acquired by CPP Wind Engineering & Air Quality Consultants who carried out two series of tests.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text
input: What were the two series of tests conducted by CPP Wind Engineering & Air Quality Consultants?

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text

output: The coefficient Δc_p12^E+ refers to the difference in pressure between the two openings and is defined in terms of the wind speed at window height.

output: Figure 5 depicts the local velocity as a function of wind angle for wind tunnel data analyzed.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> equation

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> equation
input: How is the comfort temperature Tcomf calculated?
output: T_comf = \\left\\ \\beginarrayll \\rmLow Temp Curve & \\min T_out < x \\leq \\rmBoundary Point \\\\ \\rmHigh Temp Curve & \\rmBoundary Point \\leq x < \\max T_out \\endarray\\right.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text

input: What equation is used in Step 5 for the thermal band calculation?

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> equation

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text

output: When the open elapsed time or the closed elapsed time is long enough (greater than the minimum time) the model returns to the other ventilation control defined in the Ventilation Control Mode field.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text

output: Step 4 involves the thermal comfort temperature calculation.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text
input: What components are required for pressure control in an AirLoop?
output: It requires an AirLoop with an OA mixer to reach the pressure setpoint by adjusting a relief air flow or an OA mixer and an exhaust fan in a controlled zone to reach the pressure setpoint by adjusting an exhaust fan flow rate.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text
input: What is the first step in the calculation logic for pressure control?
output: The AirflowNetwork model will run twice with zero and maximum flow rates for either the controlled zone exhaust fan or relief air flow rate. The controlled zone pressures are the return values.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text
input: What happens at zero and maximum flow rates in pressure control?
output: In general the zero flow rate of either exhaust fan or relief node will generate the maximum zone pressure while the maximum flow rate of either exhaust fan or relief node will produce the minimum zone pressure.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text
input: What does the AirflowNetwork model do if the setpoint pressure is between maximum and minimum zone pressures?
output: The AirflowNetwork model will use root solver to find a solution with calculated zone exhaust fan flow rate or relief node flow rate.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text
input: What happens if the setpoint pressure is not between maximum and minimum zone pressures?
output: Otherwise the pressure setpoint will not be met.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text
input: What happens if both maximum and minimum pressures are higher than the setpoint?
output: The maximum exhaust or outdoor flow rate will be forced.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: AirflowNetwork Model -> text
input: What happens if both maximum and minimum pressures are lower than the setpoint?
output: Then zero flow rate will be forced.

output: There are two methods used to size duct diameter and cross section area by assuming round ducts.

input: What is the aim of the hybrid modeling?
output: It aims to enhance the current energy retrofit practices not only offering more user-friendly energy modeling environments but also providing more accurate estimates of energy savings at the same time.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Hybrid Model -> text
input: What parameters are required in physics-based models and why?
output: Parameters such as interior thermal mass air infiltration rates and people count are required in physics-based models and they have significant impacts as they are driving factors for the dynamic performance of buildings.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Hybrid Model -> text
input: Why is an accurate estimate of interior thermal mass difficult?
output: An accurate estimate of interior thermal mass has been a difficult problem because the building usually has various amounts of furniture and changeable partitions.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Hybrid Model -> text
input: How does the air infiltration rate change?
output: The air infiltration rate changes in time and dynamically interacts with indoor and outdoor climatic conditions.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Hybrid Model -> text
input: Why is the accurate estimation of air infiltration rate data almost impossible?
output: The accurate estimation of the data is almost impossible to collect without a fan pressurized test which can not be easily done by typical energy modelers (Gowri et al. 2009).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Hybrid Model -> text
input: What impacts do the high uncertainty of occupants’ presence and behavior have?
output: The high uncertainty of occupants’ presence and behavior have significant impacts on building energy modeling (Clevenger & Haymaker 2001).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Hybrid Model -> text
input: Why is people count usually hard to measure in reality?
output: People count is usually hard to measure in reality which result in simplification of occupancy schedule assumptions in energy modeling.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Hybrid Model -> text
input: What does the hybrid model introduce?
output: The hybrid model introduces an approach to estimate the zone level interior thermal mass air infiltration rate and people count with measured zone air parameters in EnergyPlus.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Hybrid Model -> text
input: What gets more attention as more data are easily and freely available?
output: Solving building energy and environmental problems inversely using measured data gets more attention as more data are easily and freely available. (Yinping Zhang et al. 2015).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Hybrid Model -> text
input: What are measurements used for in hybrid modeling?
output: Measurements are to supplement to reduce discrepancies or to identify model parameters nevertheless the majority of efforts go into the derivation of the dynamic inverse modeling.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Hybrid Model -> text
input: What is inverse modeling?
output: Inverse modeling is a discipline that applies mathematical techniques to combine measurements and models.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Hybrid Model -> text
input: When can inverse modeling provide solutions?
output: Inverse modeling can provide solutions when direct measurements of model parameters are not widely available rendering the use of numerical techniques.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Hybrid Model -> text
input: Why are temperature humidity and CO$_2$ concentration data used for controls of indoor environments?
output: Temperature humidity and CO$_2$ concentration data are easily available nowadays and are used for controls of indoor environments due to a wider use of low-cost thermostats with data loggers which bring opportunities to inversely solve other hard-to-measure parameters.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Hybrid Model -> text
input: What does the new hybrid modeling approach use to improve the accuracy of building energy simulation?
output: The new hybrid modeling approach uses the inverse modeling method to improve the accuracy of the building energy simulation for existing buildings which adds measured data to solve uncertain model parameters.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Hybrid Model -> text
input: What does the hybrid modeling approach build upon?
output: The hybrid modeling approach builds upon the virtue of the physics-based model taking advantage of measured data.
